results.title: People by the billions
results.creator_credit: Donald Faser and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Earth and mankind”.
Examines the implications of the population explosion, showing that “standing room only” on our planet may become a possibility as the human race increases. A fanciful notion today, migration to another planet may hold the only hope five hundred years from now.

results.title: How plants move
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
Uses plants such as cress, beans, shamrocks and marrows to illustrate plant responses to light, gravity, water, day and night and touch. Time-lapse photography shows plant movements in detail. Gives a close-up examination of the trapping action of the venus fly-trap. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Process of pollination
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
This film considers the function of pollination and the methods by which it is brought about. The characteristics of wind- and insect-pollinated flowers are illustrated and compared and the mechanisms for avoiding self-pollination are considered. Familiar garden examples are widely used and the resources of cine- macrography and time-lapse are fully exploited.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films

results.title: Plants that climb
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
Starts with a clear visual explanation of the importance of sunlight to plants. Time-lapse photography shows in a dramatic way the methods by which plants climb, for example, using twining stems and different kinds of tendril. Suitable for primary level.

group_siblings.title: The Process of pollination
group_siblings.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films

results.title: How seeds are scattered
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
Designed for primary schools, shows how plants produce flowers and then fruits which contain seeds. Different kinds of fruits and seeds - runner beans, laburnum tree, willow seeds, thistles, sycamore tree, are used to illustrate methods of dispersal by wind, water and animals.

group_siblings.title: The Process of pollination
group_siblings.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films

results.title: How seeds are made
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
The structure of flowers is explained with close-ups to show the male and female parts, stamens and stigma. Insects are seen visiting many different flowers, both wild and cultivated. Close-ups illustrate very clearly the relationship between the shapes of flowers and the shapes of the insects which pollinate them. Wind pollinated flowers are also shown, and their pollen grains, much magnified, are compared with those of the insect-pollinated flowers. An animated diagram makes clear the process of fertilisation which follows pollination.

results.title: [Roadblocks to communication]
results.creator_credit: Russell Morash, Boston University and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Dynamics of leadership”.
The problem of communication in group discussions and lecture presentations. Sometimes ideas which are perfectly clear to the speaker are misconstrued by the listener. Examines how this can lead to misunderstandings.

results.title: Diagnosing group operations
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Dynamics of leadership”.
Uses demonstrations and discussion to consider the causes of problems that arise in groups: signs of conflict, withdrawal, factionalism, and group indecision, along with their crippling effect on the life of the group. Explains how to identify symptoms of group problems.
